2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150920100749/https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1915&dat=19790522&id=HhkiAAAAIBAJ&sjid=z3IFAAAAIBAJ&pg=6509,3809217&hl=en |archivedate=September 20, 2015 }} </ref>
===Women's roles during the Vietnam War=== {{Main|Women in the Vietnam War}} Vietnam split into two parts, North and South Vietnam, in 1954. The revolutionary socialist government in the North wanted to enhance social equity, sometimes by improving women's rights. The 1960 Marriage and Family Law, for example, banned forced marriage, child marriage, wife beating, and concubinage.<ref name="ReferenceA">Mai, T., and T. Le. Women in Vietnam. N.p.: Hanoi: Foreign Languages House, n.d. Print.</ref> The regime also focused on moving women outside of the home. They did this for the purpose of industrial development. They promoted the power of the Women's Union, which pushed for women's rights but also rallied support for the Communist government's new laws. The government of North Vietnam influenced the role of women during the war of reunification during the mid-1960s, when mobilizing women was viewed as crucial to winning the war. During this time, the Women's Union encouraged women to fulfill three main responsibilities. These were: encouraging their male relatives to fight in the war, taking all of the household burdens on themselves, and taking jobs in the industrial and agricultural workforces.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> In 1967, the Communist Party's Central Committee called for formal quotas in employment.<ref name="Werner"/> The commission asked that women occupy at least 35 percent of all jobs, and 50-70 percent of jobs in education. Most of these quotas were filled by the 1970s.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
The [[Vietnam War]] lasted from 1956 to 1975. In 1967, with the Vietnam War well under way, the Communist Party's Central Committee in North Vietnam passed resolution 153. This resolution passed formal job quotas, requiring women to hold a minimum of 35% of all jobs and 50–70% of job in the educational sector. They passed this resolution because, with so many Vietnamese men away at war, they needed more women to support the economy.<ref name="Werner">Jayne Werner, "Women, Socialism, and the Economy of Wartime North Vietnam," Studies in Comparative Communism, vol. 16 (1981), pp. 165-90. {{doi|10.1016/0039-3592(81)90005-3}}</ref> A similar infiltration occurred in the political arena, where the "percentage of women on people's councils, the major administrative bodies, increased at the provincial, district, and commune levels from 22.8, 20.8, and 16.5 percent in 1965 to 34.8, 40.0, and 40.9 percent by 1972." Although this was the greatest involvement of women in the political sphere in Vietnam's history, men maintained their hold on leadership positions across the board, not only in the political arena. When the war ended, female involvement decreased, actually sinking below its pre-war involvement rates.<ref name="Goodkind, Daniel 1995"/>
Several laws influenced women's rights in the time period following the Vietnam war and reunification. The Family Law of 1986 doubled the length of [[maternity leave]] from three to six months, while the 1988 Council of Minster's Decision number 163 gave the Women's Union the right to be involved in any decision relevant to the welfare of women or children. However, the desire for economic efficiency under the free market reforms of the new regime caused some of these reforms to be scaled back. Maternity leave, for example, was shortened to four months when employers began complaining that they lost money by hiring women. There are no other organizations like the Women's Union, as the Vietnamese government is very careful about the nongovernmental organizations they allow to exist. The Vietnamese Women's Association exists largely to increase the power of the Communist Party, so it is not always able to fully support women's interests.<ref name="Goodkind, Daniel 1995"/>
===Gender relations in post-war Vietnam=== In Vietnam during the 1960s and 1970s, the newly-powerful socialists promoted equal access to education for men and women. The reunification of North and South Vietnam after the Vietnam War, in 1976, also allowed women to take on leadership roles in politics.<ref name="Goodkind, Daniel 1995"/> One author said that Vietnam during the 1980s was "a place where, after exhausting work and furious struggle, women can be confident that they travel the path which will some day arrive at their liberation."<ref>Arlene Eisen, Women and Revolution in Vietnam (London: Zed Books, 1984).</ref>
However, some historians have argued that women's advocates in Vietnam "have been weakened in the post-reunification era due in part to the implementation of free market reforms in a nondemocratic political context."<ref name="jstor.org">{{cite journal|author=Goodkind, Daniel|title=The Vietnamese Double Marriage Squeeze |journal=International Migration Review|volume=31.1|date=1997|pages=108–127|jstor=2547260}}</ref> The resource constraints were detrimnental to women's rights, as was the political atmosphere after the war. The new state implemented free market economics but political participation was not expanded. The tight political atmosphere and resource-constraints weakened the Vietnam Women's Union, which was accustomed to speaking on behalf of women under Vietnam's single-party rule. After the war was over, it was no longer seen as a crucial organization by the government.<ref name="jstor.org"/> Political reunification also resulted in the end of the quota system and the subsequent decrease in women in the National Assembly. There was also an increase in [[occupational segregation]] as women returned to more roles within the home and men returned from the war.<ref>Allen, S. Country Gender Analysis: Vietnam. Hanoi: Swedish International Development Authority, 1992. Print.</ref> Free-market policies known as the [[Đổi Mới]] put female-headed households in rural areas at a disadvantage by limiting their access to credit.<ref>Tran, T. "The Direct Loan of Capital from the Bank to Develop Production and Gender Equality." Vietnam Social Sciences. N.p.: n.p., 1992. 25-36. Print.</ref>
==Women in contemporary society== [[File:VNese country wedding.jpg|thumb|310x310px|Traditional Vietnamese country wedding ceremony]]Women occupy both the domestic and outside sector in contemporary Vietnam. Women's participation in the economy, government, and society has increased.<ref name=":3" /> In the domestic sphere, little progress has been made to improve gender relations. Traditional [[Confucianism|Confucian]] [[Patriarchy|patriarchal]] values have continued to persist, as well as a continued emphasis on the family unit. This has comprised the main criticism of Vietnam Women's Union, an organization that works towards advancing women's rights.<ref name=":0" /> Furthermore, recent shifts in Vietnam's [[Human sex ratio|sex ratio]] show an increased number of men outnumbering women, which many researchers have stated to in part be caused by the [[two-child policy]] in Vietnam.<ref name=":10" />
===Family===
==== Marriage ==== Following their colonization by European powers, many lost their standing and were placed in the [[Separate spheres|domestic sphere]]. Instead of being involved in their society, women worked as trade intermediaries and were expected to marry and become housewives.<ref>Lockard, Craig A. Southeast Asia in World History. Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2009.</ref> This shift in gender roles became a new cultural practice and lasted for years until the Vietnam War, when women in rural Vietnam became discouraged from marrying and female singlehood became a growing trend. A common belief was that after the mid-twenties, women were considered undesirable and marriage was a way of life. The cap for marriage was at this age because after this time, women could no longer bare children, a necessity for the survival of the family name. In addition, the notion of "a one-person, self-sufficient household was not very acceptable" <ref name="Rural North Viet Nam 2002">Werner, Jayne Susan, and Khuat Thu Hong. "Too Late to Marry: Failure, Fate or Fortune? Female Singlehood in Rural North Viet Nam." In Gender, Household, State: đỏ̂i Mới in Việt Nam, 89-110. Ithaca, N.Y.: Southeast Asia Program, Cornell University, 2002.</ref> and was looked at as selfish and lonely. After the age of twenty-five, single women enter a period where they "make the transition from temporary to permanent non-marriage." <ref name="Rural North Viet Nam 2002" /> As they go through this period, society perceived them as being "wishful" or even "regretful".<ref name="Rural North Viet Nam 2002" /> However, when women were interviewed, nearly all showed no sign of remorse from rejecting marriage proposals during their prime ages for marriage. They were happy with their decision to opt out of a possible "miserable" life with a husband.<ref name="Rural North Viet Nam 2002" />
Familial obligations, especially during the Vietnam War, forced many women to put off marriage until they reached an age where they were viewed as "unfavorable". From a young age, the eldest child of a Vietnamese family had a variety of obligations to uphold. One of which was having to care for their younger siblings. During time of war, it was difficult for the parents to overlook agricultural labor while taking care of all their children.<ref name="Rural North Viet Nam 2002" /> If the eldest daughter were to be married off, the family would lose a hand of labor. Because of this obligation, women rejected offerings of marriage. After the war, women continued to help around the household and replaced the men they lost in combat. Although many still had proposals for marriage, they believed that it was fate that they had been single for that long and that they were meant for singlehood. The gender imbalance that followed the Vietnam War was also a cause in the rise of single women. It was hard for them because men living in rural areas were hesitant to marry them. In addition, those who work at state farms and forestry stations were stationed in remote areas. This limited women from socializing with the opposite sex.
Studies have shown there are marriage discrepancies between rural and urban areas in Vietnam today. According to Nguyen et al., women from rural areas were shown to enter marriage at a younger age than women from urban areas.<ref name=":7" /> Furthermore, evidence has shown that there is a difference in marital and familial values between north and south Vietnam.<ref name=":7" /><ref name=":11" /> According to one study, these differences between the north and south regions are likely due to their separation during the mid-20th century, as well as the degree of socialist or western influences on the north and south, respectively. The cultural differences between northern and southern Vietnam include "marriage rituals, family living arrangement, household composition, and premarital sexual behaviors" according to a study by Teerawichitchainan et al.<ref name=":11">{{Cite journal|last=Teerawichitchainan|first=Bussarawan|last2=Knodel|first2=John|last3=Loi|first3=Vu Manh|last4=Huy|first4=Vu Tuan|date=2010-01-01|title=The Gender Division of Household Labor in Vietnam: Cohort Trends and Regional Variations|jstor=41604338|journal=Journal of Comparative Family Studies|volume=41|issue=1|pages=57–85}}</ref>
====Domestic role==== {{Duplication|section=yes|date=March 2015}} [[Confucianism]]'s emphasis on the family still impacts Vietnamese women's lives, especially in rural areas, where it espouses the importance of premarital female virginity and condemns abortion and divorce.<ref>Nguyen Khac Vien (1975) Confucianism and Marxism in Vietnam, in: David Marr & Jayne Werner (Eds) Tradition and Revolution in Vietnam, pp. 15–52 (Berkeley, Indochina Resources Center).</ref> According to a 2006 study, over the past decades, little progression in gender relations have been made. Household chores and labor are still primarily performed by Vietnamese women; however, women in Vietnam have shown increased influence in familial decisions, such as household budgets and the education of the children. In terms of childcare responsibility, men have shown an increased participation at the earlier ages of childcare, though women overall still bear the main responsibility.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Knodel|first=John|last2=Loi|first2=Vu Manh|last3=Jayakody|first3=Rukmalie|last4=Huy|first4=Vu Tuan|date=2005-03-01|title=Gender Roles in the Family|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/17441730500125888|journal=Asian Population Studies|volume=1|issue=1|pages=69–92|doi=10.1080/17441730500125888|issn=1744-1730}}</ref> Women are seen primarily as mothers, and are considered to have shown "respect" to their husband's lineage if they give birth to a boy.<ref>Rydstrøm, Helle. "Sexual desires and ‘social evils’: young women in rural Vietnam." Gender, Place and Culture 13, no. 3 (2006): 283-301.</ref> While patrilineal ancestor worship shows girls as "outside lineage" (''họ ngoại''), it consider boys to be "inside lineage" (''họ nội''). Vietnamese society tends to follow the ancestral line through males, pushing women to the periphery. Vietnam has a two child policy. Some families want at least one boy, but would prefer two boys to two girls, so they use ultrasound machines to determine the baby's sex to later abort female offspring.<ref>Zeng Yi et al., "Causes and Implications of the Recent Increase in the Reported Sex Ratio of Birth in China," Population and Development Review, vol. 19 (June 1993), pp. 283-302; Daniel Goodkind, "Rising Sex Ratios at Birth in Confucian Asia: A Summary of Interpretive Puzzles" (Unpublished manuscript, 1994).</ref>
The main religion in Vietnam are traditional folk beliefs (see [[Vietnamese folk religion]]). This is not an organized religion, however it does adopt many Confucian views. One of the main views that it takes from Confucius is the Patrilineal Society. Men are the head of the family and more their lineage is to be protected. As it pertains to motherhood, Vietnam women are seen as and used primarily as mothers. Female virginity is of extreme importance, especially in rural areas, and the Society condemns abortion and female divorce. If a women wants to show respect to her husband, the best way she can do that is to bear him a son.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-23501757|title=Vietnam: Where saying 'I love you' is impossible - BBC News|work=bbc.com|accessdate=17 June 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160817012538/http://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-23501757|archivedate=17 August 2016|df=}}</ref>
There are several patterns in birth rates amongst Vietnamese women. In one 2008 study by Nguyen et al., most women were found to have given birth by the time they reached age 20. However, the same study has found that the higher education level a woman received, the later the age at which she gives birth to her first child.<ref name=":7">{{Cite journal|last=Luc|first=Nguyen|last2=Thang|first2=Nguyen Minh|last3=Swenson|first3=Ingrid|last4=San|first4=Pham Bich|date=1993-07-01|title=Selected determinants of fertility in vietnam: age at marriage, marriage to first birth interval and age at first birth|url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/journal-of-biosocial-science/article/selected-determinants-of-fertility-in-vietnam-age-at-marriage-marriage-to-first-birth-interval-and-age-at-first-birth/E4E28F535BF43E24E5D5378111B54B96|journal=Journal of Biosocial Science|volume=25|issue=3|pages=303–310|doi=10.1017/S0021932000020642|issn=1469-7599|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161114170608/https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/journal-of-biosocial-science/article/selected-determinants-of-fertility-in-vietnam-age-at-marriage-marriage-to-first-birth-interval-and-age-at-first-birth/E4E28F535BF43E24E5D5378111B54B96|archivedate=2016-11-14|df=}}</ref>
==== Domestic violence ==== The issue of [[domestic violence]] has faced scrutiny in Vietnam. In 2007, Vietnamese legislation passed the Law on Prevention and Control Domestic Violence, which reported that 32% of Vietnamese women have suffered sexual violence from their spouses, while 54% of women in Vietnam have suffered from emotional violence. Speculation has rose on the viability of divorce as a solution to those in situations of domestic violence.<ref name=":4" /> This is due to the prevalent local attitudes and measures taken towards preventing divorce in order to preserve the family unit, rather than helping victims escape domestic abuse. Additionally, surveys have indicated that 87% of domestic violence victims in Vietnam do not seek support for their situation.<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=Vu|first=Ha Song|last2=Schuler|first2=Sidney|last3=Hoang|first3=Tu Anh|last4=Quach|first4=Trang|date=2014-07-03|title=Divorce in the context of domestic violence against women in Vietnam|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/13691058.2014.896948|journal=Culture, Health & Sexuality|volume=16|issue=6|pages=634–647|doi=10.1080/13691058.2014.896948|issn=1369-1058}}</ref>
In a study comparing Chinese and Vietnamese attitudes towards women, more Vietnamese than Chinese said that the male should dominate the family and a wife had to provide sex to her husband at his will.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tV6MAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA294&dq=vietnamese+wife+beating+Chinese&hl=en&sa=X&ei=xeNdVc3pFMqYyASt14C4BA&ved=0CDcQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=vietnamese%20wife%20beating%20Chinese&f=false|title=Race, Crime, and Justice : A Reader|date=2013-10-18|website=Books.google.com|page=29|accessdate=2016-06-17|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160617154518/https://books.google.com/books?id=tV6MAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA294&dq=vietnamese+wife+beating+Chinese&hl=en&sa=X&ei=xeNdVc3pFMqYyASt14C4BA&ved=0CDcQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=vietnamese%20wife%20beating%20Chinese&f=false|archivedate=2016-06-17|df=}}</ref> Violence against women was supported by more Vietnamese than Chinese.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iaQ3AAAAQBAJ&pg=PA134&dq=vietnamese+wife+beating+Chinese&hl=en&sa=X&ei=xeNdVc3pFMqYyASt14C4BA&ved=0CHAQ6AEwCw#v=onepage&q=vietnamese%20wife%20beating%20Chinese&f=false|title=Contemporary Clinical Practice with Asian Immigrants: A Relational Framework ...|date=2013-07-31|website=Books.google.com|page=134|author1=Irene Chung|author2=Tazuko Shibusawa|accessdate=2016-06-17|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160624051604/https://books.google.com/books?id=iaQ3AAAAQBAJ&pg=PA134&dq=vietnamese+wife+beating+Chinese&hl=en&sa=X&ei=xeNdVc3pFMqYyASt14C4BA&ved=0CHAQ6AEwCw#v=onepage&q=vietnamese%20wife%20beating%20Chinese&f=false|archivedate=2016-06-24|df=}}</ref> Domestic violence was more accepted by Vietnamese women than Chinese women.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=i1q4AwAAQBAJ&pg=PA142&dq=vietnamese+wife+beating+Chinese&hl=en&sa=X&ei=xeNdVc3pFMqYyASt14C4BA&ved=0CGUQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=vietnamese%20wife%20beating%20Chinese&f=false|title=Diversity and Complexity in Feminist Therapy|date=|website=Books.google.com|page=142|author1=Maria P P Root|author2=Laura Brown|accessdate=2016-06-17|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160610055027/https://books.google.com/books?id=i1q4AwAAQBAJ&pg=PA142&dq=vietnamese+wife+beating+Chinese&hl=en&sa=X&ei=xeNdVc3pFMqYyASt14C4BA&ved=0CGUQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=vietnamese%20wife%20beating%20Chinese&f=false|archivedate=2016-06-10|df=}}</ref>
==== International marriage ==== Some Vietnamese women from [[Lào Cai]] who married Chinese men stated that among their reasons for doing so was that Vietnamese men beat their wives, engaged in affairs with mistresses, and refused to help their wives with chores, while Chinese men actively helped their wives carry out chores and care for them.<ref name="Chan2013">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cjoVAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA113&dq=vietnamese+wife+beating&hl=en&sa=X&ei=0uJdVcf_MYHiyAS31oDwAw&ved=0CDcQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=vietnamese%20wife%20beating&f=false|title=Vietnamese-Chinese Several cases have occurred where Vietnamese women were abducted or deceived to be sold to Chinese men.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scmp.com/news/china/society/article/2094928/chinese-gang-trial-abducting-27-vietnamese-women-and-selling-them|title=Gang on trial for abducting Vietnamese to sell as wives in China|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.economist.com/china/2017/11/04/demand-for-wives-in-china-endangers-women-who-live-on-its-borders|title=Demand for wives in China endangers women who live on its borders|publisher=}}</ref> Totalling several thousands, in a significant number of cases the victims were underage.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.inkstonenews.com/society/vietnamese-child-brides-sold-china/article/2151249|title=Sold to China: Vietnam’s 6,000 child brides|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scmp.com/week-asia/society/article/2151075/vietnam-without-love-child-brides-china|title=From Vietnam, without love: the child brides of China|publisher=}}</ref>
=== Sex ratio === Recent studies have shown a shift in Vietnam's [[sex ratio]] to match that of other countries in the region, where proportions are uneven and men outnumber women. In 2006, the sex ratio was found to be 110 men per 100 women throughout Vietnam, higher than the established normal sex ratio of 106 men per 100 women. Researchers have pointed to the preference for a small family size, which stems from Vietnam's two-child policy, preference for sons, and increase in ultrasound and abortion usage for the cause of the sex ratio shift.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Pham|first=Bang Nguyen|last2=Hall|first2=Wayne|last3=Hill|first3=Peter S.|last4=Rao|first4=Chalapati|date=2008-01-01|title=Analysis of Socio-Political and Health Practices Influencing Sex Ratio at Birth in Viet Nam|jstor=25475446|journal=Reproductive Health Matters|volume=16|issue=32|pages=176–184}}</ref>
==== Sex-selective abortions ==== In 1988, Vietnam introduced its "[[two-child policy]]." This policy was introduced because of the population size of Vietnam. However, because of the policy, if a woman gave birth to a son first, the chances of her having a second child dropped dramatically even if she desired to have more children. If a woman gave birth to a daughter first, she was more than likely to have a second child even if she did not wish to have additional children. This is because families in most cases would rather have at least one boy. To ensure the sex of children in recent years, Vietnamese families have increasingly been using ultrasound technology and enhancing and developing the produced images. This often leads to the abortion of female offspring.<ref name=":10">{{cite journal|year=1995|title=Vietnam's one-or-two-child policy in action|journal=[[Population and Development Review]]|volume=21|issue=1|pages=85–111|jstor=2137414?|author=Daniel M. Goodkind}}</ref> As of late 20th century, economist [[Amartya Sen]] has noted the recent advent of sex-selective abortions to further increase the phenomenon of "missing women" worldwide. This notion alludes to the worsening of the women-to-men ratio, with men continuing to outnumber women.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Amartya|first=Sen|date=2003-12-04|title=Missing women—revisited|url=http://www.bmj.com/content/327/7427/1297|journal=BMJ|language=en|volume=327|issue=7427|pages=1297–1298|doi=10.1136/bmj.327.7427.1297|issn=0959-8138|pmc=286281|pmid=14656808|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170717115447/http://www.bmj.com/content/327/7427/1297|archivedate=2017-07-17|df=}}</ref>
==== Female mortality ==== Since 1970, overall child mortality rates have declined. However, contrary to nearby countries such as India and China, male child mortality rates have shown to be higher than female child mortality rates most years from 1970-2000. In a study done by Pham et al., boys are 30% more likely than girls to die before a specified age.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Pham|first=Thong Le|last2=Kooreman|first2=Peter|last3=Koning|first3=Ruud H.|last4=Wiersma|first4=Doede|date=2012-06-19|title=Gender patterns in Vietnam’s child mortality|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s00148-012-0425-9|journal=Journal of Population Economics|language=en|volume=26|issue=1|pages=303–322|doi=10.1007/s00148-012-0425-9|issn=0933-1433}}</ref> [[File:Vietnamese village school - panoramio.jpg|thumb|321x321px|School classroom in the rural district of [[Tam Đường District, Lai Châu|Tam Đường]]]]
===Education=== Overall literacy rates across Vietnam are high, with access to education being relatively equal between males and females. However, regional differences are still apparent, especially amongst the mountainous northern regions. For example, in one study, the region of [[Lai Châu Province|Lai Chau]] was found to have a literacy rate for men double that of the women's literacy rate in the region.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kelly|first=Kristy|date=2000-01-01|title=The higher education system in Vietnam|url=http://www.nzdl.org/gsdl/collect/literatu/index/assoc/HASH2125.dir/doc.pdf|journal=World Education News and Reviews|volume=13|issue=3|pages=5–6|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161012224744/http://www.nzdl.org/gsdl/collect/literatu/index/assoc/HASH2125.dir/doc.pdf|archivedate=2016-10-12|df=}}</ref>
There is a gender gap in education, with males being more likely to attend school and sustain their education than females.<ref>Project of Children Statistics, 1989. Profiles of Children and Women zn Vietnam (Nhung van de ve tre em va phu nu Viet Nam) (Hanoi: General Statistical Office, 1989).</ref> Women and men tend to be segregated into different jobs, with more women serving in educational, communications, and public services than men.
=== Economy === In contemporary Vietnam, there has been significant economic advancement for women, especially for middle-class Vietnamese women. Middle-class women have increasingly become more involved in the workforce sector outside of the house, with 83% of "working-age women" being involved in the labor force.<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Kelly|first=KRISTY|date=2011-01-01|title=Vietnam case study (preliminary findings): Women in educational leadership and management|url=https://www.academia.edu/download/14087152/sem313_17_eng.pdf|journal=A paper presented during the Gender Equality in Education: Looking beyond parity. An IIEP evidence based policy forum held in Paris between|pages=3–4}}</ref> These women have been taking on professions dealing with a variety of fields such as sales, marketing, and advertising. Furthermore, women in the contemporary workforce and economy experience much higher wages than the generations before them.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Higgins|first=Rylan|date=2015-11-01|title=Is It My Job to Make Him Care? Middle-Class Women and Gender Inequality in Ho Chi Minh City|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/awr.12069/abstract|journal=Anthropology of Work Review|language=en|volume=36|issue=2|pages=74–86|doi=10.1111/awr.12069|issn=1548-1417}}</ref> However, research has shown that many inequalities for women still exist, with women still receiving uneven employment benefits compared to their male counterparts.<ref name=":2" /> According to one study, 76% of women in the labor force are concentrated in the agricultural sector. And although under 10% of women in the labor force work in textile industry, 80% of laborers in the textile industry are women.<ref name=":9">{{Cite journal|last=Truong|first=Thi Thuy Hang|date=2008-09-01|title=Women’s Leadership in Vietnam: Opportunities and Challenges|url=http://www.journals.uchicago.edu/doi/10.1086/588432|journal=Signs: Journal of Women in Culture and Society|volume=34|issue=1|pages=16–21|doi=10.1086/588432|issn=0097-9740}}</ref>
Local credit associations do not feel secure giving loans to single mothers, which has resulted in a poverty increase for households that are led by a woman.<ref>T. V. A. Tran, "The Direct Loan of Capital from the Bank to Development Production and Gender Equality," Social Sciences (Vietnam), vol. 34 (1992), pp. 25-26.</ref>
==== Gender pay gap ==== The average wage in the country of Vietnam was US$1,540 in 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thanhniennews.com/business/menwomen-wage-gap-widens-in-vietnam-3283.html|title=Men-women wage gap widens in Vietnam | Business | Thanh Nien Daily|date=2013-03-07|website=Thanhniennews.com|accessdate=2016-06-17|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160630122227/http://www.thanhniennews.com/business/menwomen-wage-gap-widens-in-vietnam-3283.html|archivedate=2016-06-30|df=}}</ref> In 2011, studies showed "that women earn 13% less than men."<ref name=":12">{{Cite news|url=http://www.ilo.org/hanoi/Informationresources/Publicinformation/Pressreleases/WCMS_206104/lang--en/index.htm|title=Despite high labour force participation rate for women, gender pay gap on the rise|date=2013-03-07|language=en|access-date=2016-11-16|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160810141012/http://www.ilo.org/hanoi/Informationresources/Publicinformation/Pressreleases/WCMS_206104/lang--en/index.htm|archivedate=2016-08-10|df=}}</ref> The 2012 survey on workers’ salaries carried out by the Vietnam General Confederation of Labour (VGCL) in enterprises nationwide revealed that female workers’ salaries are only 70-80% of their male colleagues’.<ref name=":12" /> The global average gender pay gap is hovering around seventeen percent<ref name="WCMS_206104">{{cite web|url=http://www.ilo.org/hanoi/Informationresources/Publicinformation/Pressreleases/WCMS_206104/lang--en/index.htm|title=Despite high labour force participation rate for women, gender pay gap on the rise|date=7 March 2013|work=ilo.org|accessdate=17 June 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160510085829/http://www.ilo.org/hanoi/Informationresources/Publicinformation/Pressreleases/WCMS_206104/lang--en/index.htm|archivedate=10 May 2016|df=}}</ref> According to Nguyen Kim Lan, ILO national project coordinator, the only 2 occupational fields where pay is equal is in logistics, and household care.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thanhniennews.com/business/menwomen-wage-gap-widens-in-vietnam-3283.html|title=Men-women wage gap widens in Vietnam|work=thanhniennews.com|accessdate=17 June 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160630122227/http://www.thanhniennews.com/business/menwomen-wage-gap-widens-in-vietnam-3283.html|archivedate=30 June 2016|df=}}</ref> One reason for the disparity is that companies view women as wanting to stay at home and perform more gender role duties .More than seventy percent of laborers in Vietnam are women. The International Labour Organizations recently stated that the gender pay gap has started to increase, according to the ILO Global Wage Report during the 2012-13 period, compared to 1999-2007.<ref name="WCMS_206104" /> A two percent increase in the gap was recorded in Vietnam in the period.<ref name="WCMS_206104" />
=== Politics === Women's participation in the National Assembly is at its lowest since 1997.<ref name="vn.undp.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.vn.undp.org/content/dam/vietnam/docs/Publications/31204_Women_s_Representation_in_Leadership_in_Viet_Nam.pdf|title=Women's Representation in Leadership in Vietnam|website=Vn.undp.org|format=PDF|accessdate=2016-06-17|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305005416/http://www.vn.undp.org/content/dam/vietnam/docs/Publications/31204_Women_s_Representation_in_Leadership_in_Viet_Nam.pdf|archivedate=2016-03-05|df=}}</ref> Little progress has been made to move ahead of the 30% average of women's representation in Vietnam. Within the Vietnam Communist Party, women's membership has slowly climbed, and in 2010 was 33%. This is a significant increase from 2005 when women's membership was only 21.9%. Despite this increase, the membership of women in the party is still less than men. Additionally, the number of women leaders in key positions such as in the Politburo, Central Committee and the Secretariat remains low.<ref name="vn.undp.org" /> On the regional level, women occupy 23% of district positions, as well as 23% of municipal positions.<ref name=":9" /> Like the United Nation Millennium Development Goals, the Vietnamese government has also developed their own set of goals committed to increasing the percent of women in government, which in 2011 was still at 30%.<ref name=":9" /><ref name="vn.undp.org" /> One example of Vietnam's efforts to improve women representation are in the National Strategy for the Advancement of Women, which set goals to be reached by 2010.<ref name=":9" /> However, Vietnam has fallen short of many of its stated goals. There are several reasons that the government has not been able to meet its quota to have more women in government. The reasons include factors such as "inadequate government regulations, lack of implementation of existing policies, cultural factors, and inherent systemic bias towards men."<ref name="vn.undp.org" /> Many women that want to engage in politics are often discouraged because of age-related training eligibility criteria and a retirement age that is five years earlier than males, with males having a retirement age of 60 and women having a retirement age of 55.<ref name=":9" /><ref name="vn.undp.org" /> Workplace attitudes are challenges for women to achieve their aspiration of leadership positions. Unlike males, women are harassed much more in their occupations, and promotion is dependent upon the supervisors discretion and how he feels about gender promotion. There are few women role models for young women to follow or to be inspired by. Many women in Vietnam do not see themselves as becoming leaders because there a lack of female leaders to look up to. This occurs because of messages that are expressed socially in media, home, and education.<ref name="vn.undp.org" />
Currently, the position of the Vice President of Vietnam is held by [[Đặng Thị Ngọc Thịnh]], with this being the highest office to be held by a woman in Vietnam. However, most data has pointed to a majority of positions in recent office terms being held by men. For example, during the 2002 to 2007 term, all of the minister positions comprising the government cabinet were held by men. These statistics have constituted many leaders advocating for greater representation for women in leader positions. To implement this goal, a National Strategy on Gender Equality was recently implemented in 2011 through to 2020.<ref name=":3" />
=== Human trafficking === {{Main|Human trafficking in Vietnam}} Since the 1980s, some women from Vietnam have become victims of [[Bride kidnapping|kidnapping]], the bride-buying trade, and [[Human trafficking in the People's Republic of China|human trafficking]] and [[Prostitution in China|prostitution]] in [[China]].,<ref name="WSJ2">{{cite web|url=http://www.wright.edu/~tdung/bride_vn.htm|title=Vietnamese Women are Kidnapped and Later Sold in China as Brides|last2=Lee-Young|first2=Joanne|date=3 August 1999|last3=Forney|first3=Matt|last1=Marshall|first1=Samantha|work=[[Wall Street Journal]]|accessdate=2 May 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111119021150/http://www.wright.edu/~tdung/bride_vn.htm|archivedate=19 November 2011|df=}}</ref> Taiwan, South Korea, and in the cases of human trafficking, prostitution and [[sexual slavery]], [[Cambodia]]. The present-day struggle of the Vietnamese female victims of "[[International marriage agency|bride-brokers]]" can be summarized by the larger-than-life poem known as "[[The Tale of Kieu]]," which narrates the story of a female protagonist of Vietnam who was purchased by foreigners and was violated, yet kept fighting back against her captors and offenders.<ref name="WSJ2" />
The main human rights issue in Southeast Asia is [[Human trafficking]]. According to one study, Southeast Asia is a large source of human trafficking, with many individuals who fall victim to human trafficking being sent to Australia.<ref name=":8">{{Cite journal|last=Larsen|first=J. J.|year=2010|title=Migration and people trafficking in Southeast Asia|url=https://search.informit.com.au/documentSummary;dn=846187365487985;res=IELHSS|journal=Trends & Issues in Crime and Criminal Justice|publisher=Canberra, Australia: Australian Institute of Criminology|volume=401}}</ref> Vietnam, as well as other countries such as Cambodia, Laos, and the Philippines, are major source countries for human trafficking.<ref name=":8" /> Southeast Asian countries preference for boys over girls is further tipping the balance between the sexes in the region, already skewed by a strong bias for boys.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/id/21566321/ns/health-childrens_health/t/vietnams-desire-baby-boys-skews-gender/#.VHtgoNyGtBU|title=Vietnam's desire for baby boys skews gender|date=31 October 2007|work=nbcnews.com|accessdate=17 June 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160306211944/http://www.nbcnews.com/id/21566321/ns/health-childrens_health/t/vietnams-desire-baby-boys-skews-gender/#.VHtgoNyGtBU|archivedate=6 March 2016|df=}}</ref> The trend has led to increased trafficking of women. While many of the victims that are a part of human trafficking are forced/kidnapped/enslaved, others were lured in under the assumption that they were getting a better job.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.issues.cc/complaints/human-trafficking/human-trafficking-in-southeast-asia|title=Human Trafficking - Human Trafficking In SouthEast Asia|work=issues.cc|accessdate=17 June 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160327084454/http://www.issues.cc/complaints/human-trafficking/human-trafficking-in-southeast-asia|archivedate=27 March 2016|df=}}</ref> According to a policy brief on human trafficking in Southeast Asia, although victims include girls, women, boys, and men, the majority are women. Women tend to be more highly targeted by traffickers due to the fact that they are seeking opportunity in an area of the world where limited economic opportunities are available for them. Unskilled and poorly educated women are commonly led into human trafficking. According to the [[UNODC]] report, the numbers for women and men in forced labor may be skewed due to the fact that only a few countries released the numbers for adult men.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.unodc.org/unodc/human-trafficking/|title=UNODC - Human Trafficking|work=unodc.org|accessdate=17 June 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160715092225/http://www.unodc.org/unodc/human-trafficking/|archivedate=15 July 2016|df=}}</ref> However what is known is that women are trafficked the most. The main causes of human trafficking in Southeast Asia are universal factors such as poverty and globalization. Industrialization is arguably also another factor of human trafficking. Many scholars argue that industrialization of booming economies, like that of [[Thailand]] and [[Singapore]], created a draw for poor migrants seeking upward mobility and individuals wanting to leave war torn countries.These migrants were an untapped resource in growing economies that had already exhausted the cheap labor from within its borders. A high supply of migrant workers seeking employment and high demand from an economy seeking cheap labor creates a perfect combination for human traffickers to thrive. The sex industry emerged in [[Southeast Asia]] in the mid 20th century as a way for women to generate more income for struggling migrants and locals trying to support families or themselves. Sex industries first catered to military personnel on leave from bases but as military installations began to recede the industry turned its attention to growing tourism. Even as the industry is looked down upon today there is still a large underground market that is demanding from traffickers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.humantrafficking.org/regions/south_and_central_asia|title=HumanTrafficking.org - Regions: South & Central Asia|work=humantrafficking.org|accessdate=17 June 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160530221901/http://www.humantrafficking.org/regions/south_and_central_asia|archivedate=30 May 2016|df=}}</ref>
Between 2005 and 2009, 6,000 women, as well as younger girls, were found to be in the human trafficking statistic. The majority of the women and girls are trafficked to China, 30% are trafficked to Cambodia, and the remaining 10% are trafficked to the destinations across the world.<ref>The trafficking of women and children from Vietnam. Child Exploitation and Online Protection Centre in association with the British Embassy, Hanoi. (2011)</ref>
===Vietnam Women's Union=== [[File:Vietnamese women in canthao district.jpg|thumb|251x251px|Members of Vietnam Women's Union attending a [[Disaster preparedness|Disaster Preparedness]] workshop in Can Thao district, southern Vietnam]]In recent decades, [[Vietnam]] has stressed the importance of gender equality. To address this goal, the Vietnam Women's Union, an organization founded in 1930 under the [[Communist Party of Vietnam|Vietnam Communist Party]], has pursued the advancement of women in many arenas; however, they also stress many aspects of Confucian doctrine that keeps a male-dominated hierarchy in place. As of 2000, their membership has expanded to 11 million, which compromises for 60% of the female population in Vietnam over the age of 18. Because of their large membership, the Vietnam Women's Union has frequently been regarded as the representative for women in politics. Therefore, the VWU frequently advises during the policy-making of gender-related or women's issues.<ref name=":1" /> However, their role has been disputed due to its shortcomings in promoting women's right effectively.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Schuler|first=Sidney Ruth|last2=Anh|first2=Hoang tu|last3=Ha|first3=Vu Song|last4=Minh|first4=Tran Hung|last5=Mai|first5=Bui Thi Thanh|last6=Thien|first6=Pham vu|date=2006-01-01|title=Constructions of Gender in Vietnam: In Pursuit of the 'Three Criteria'|jstor=4005524|journal=Culture, Health & Sexuality|volume=8|issue=5|pages=383–394}}</ref>
In the 1980s, the Vietnam Women's Union<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hoilhpn.org.vn/?Lang=EN|title=Hội liên hiệp Phụ nữ - Việt nam|work=hoilhpn.org.vn|accessdate=17 June 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160802030459/http://hoilhpn.org.vn/?Lang=EN|archivedate=2 August 2016|df=}}</ref> increased paid maternity leave and received a promise that they would be asked before the government implemented any policies that could potentially affect the welfare of women. However, the increased maternity leave was restored to its original length a few years later. While there are limits in the Vietnam Women's Union that prohibit gender change in certain areas, there does not seem to be other organized civil society groups that are fighting for women's rights. Two areas that have seen little change throughout recent decades are the roles women play in the family, specifically motherhood, and the human rights problems women traditionally face in the region.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://userpages.aug.com/captbarb/femvetsnam.html|title=Military Women in Vietnam|work=aug.com|accessdate=17 June 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160619094058/http://userpages.aug.com/captbarb/femvetsnam.html|archivedate=19 June 2016|df=}}</ref>
In 2001, the Vietnam Women's Union was appointed to head the planning of a new legislation, a Law on Gender Equality, which set out to equalize conditions between both genders.<ref name=":5" /> The legislation included several stipulations, including laws pertaining to retirement age for both men and women. The law was in its final legislation processes in 2006, with it going into effect mid 2007.<ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|last=Kelly|first=Kristy|date=2009|title=Obliged to Mother, Required to Retire: Gender, Class, Equality and Retirement Rights in Vietnam.|journal=Conference Papers -- American Sociological Association|volume=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.un.org/press/en/2007/wom1593.doc.htm|title=NEW LAW ON GENDER EQUALITY WILL GREATLY IMPROVE VIET NAM’S LEGAL REGIME FOR WOMEN’S ADVANCEMENT, ANTI-DISCRIMINATION COMMITTEE TOLD {{!}} Meetings Coverage and Press Releases|website=www.un.org|access-date=2016-10-11|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161105170007/http://www.un.org/press/en/2007/wom1593.doc.htm|archivedate=2016-11-05|df=}}</ref>
==== Criticism ==== Their focus on Confucian values which uphold a male-dominated hierarchy has received criticism.<ref name=":0" /> In numerous studies, the VWU has been criticized for its lack of action against gender norms while placing too much emphasis on family structure.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Waibel|first=Gabi|last2=Glück|first2=Sarah|date=2013-07-01|title=More than 13 million: mass mobilisation and gender politics in the Vietnam Women's Union|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/13552074.2013.802148|journal=Gender & Development|volume=21|issue=2|pages=343–361|doi=10.1080/13552074.2013.802148|issn=1355-2074}}</ref> Furthermore, while their efforts have worked towards improving women's status, the VWU faces criticism for their lack of advocacy towards women's power.<ref name=":1" />
